Name: Honduras Finca Gaby
Review: ong>Certified Fair Trade coffee buyers with a taste for quiet adventure. The note we are calling brie cheese is not unpleasant, and resonates with the savory-sweet structure and rose-and-cocoa aromatics.

Name: 423 Blend
Review: ong>A roast on the darkish end of medium turns the fruit and chocolate crisp and deep.

Name: Panama Altieri Natural Geisha
Review: ong>Those who seek a beautifully structured coffee that delivers a lyrically complex aroma, rich, seductive flavor and crisp, authoritative finish.

Name: Ethiopia Adado Sulula
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a complexly fruit and floral-toned yet cleanly balanced rendition of the great Ethiopia dried-in-the-fruit profile.

Name: Greenwell Estate Hawaii Kona Natural Espresso
Review: ong>Those who value a bright yet lushly juicy straight shot and an authoritative fruit-nuanced presence in cappuccino-scaled milk.
Coffee Origin: Kona growing region, Big Island of Hawaii

Name: Greenwell Estate Hawaii Kona Peaberry Natural
Review: ong>Those who value crisp sweetness and complex fruit in an unusual dried-in-the-fruit coffee from a celebrated origin.
Coffee Origin: Kona growing region, Big Island of Hawaii

Name: Organic Espresso
Review: ong>Virtuoso calls this a “traditional European style” espresso, and so it is. Lovers of the new style of brighter, high-toned, lighter-bodied espressos may not like it. Traditionalists will.

Name: Organic Holiday Blend
Review: ong>Complex, original and subtly layered organic holiday blend.

Name: Bean Brain Reserve Perla Negra Costa Rica
Review: ong>A fine dried-in-the-fruit coffee at the intriguing intersection of cherryish fruit, chocolate, whisky and deep, lily-like flowers.
Coffee Origin: Alajuela growing region, Central Valley, Costa Rica

Name: Kemgin Ninety Plus
Review: ong>The intricate, fragrant overlapping of sweet floral and savory herb tendencies may particularly appeal to those who enjoy complex aperitifs and digestifs.
Coffee Origin: Wellega, Sidama and Yirgacheffe growing regions, southern and western Ethiopia

Name: Ethiopia Nigusse Lemma
Review: ong>Those who value an elegantly subtle version of the fruit-and-floral-toned exuberance typical of fine dried-in-the-fruit or “natural”-processed Ethiopian coffees.

Name: Colombia Maximino Gutierrez
Review: ong>Classicists. A superb Colombia, sweet yet brisk, balanced in structure and complete in nuance.

Name: Kenya Nyeri AA
Review: ong>Nice Kenya for those who avoid the often bright Kenya acidity but value the pungent, savory-sweet berry and dark chocolate tendencies of the type.

Name: Ethiopia Duromina Organic
Review: ong>Those who value subtlety and resonance in a gently roast-rounded, sweetly bright and floral wet-processed Ethiopia.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Natural Process
Review: ong>A classic dried-in-the-fruit Ethiopia with the usual lush fruit rounded to a crisp, floral-toned chocolate by a tactful darkish roast.

Name: Panama Don Pepe Estate Geisha Single-Origin Espresso
Review: ong>Those who value soaring, extraordinary complexity and originality of aroma and flavor in both straight shot and cappuccino-scaled milk. The price makes this a striking value for a coffee this distinguished.

Name: Ichamama Kenya
Review: ong>Those who lean toward the sweet and juicy side of the classic intricacy and elegance of the great Kenya profile.

Name: Hambela Ethiopia Natural
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a classic dried-in-the-fruit, “natural” profile, fruit-and-brandy-saturated but clean finishing.
Coffee Origin: Hambela District, Oromia growing region, southern Ethiopia

Name: El Aguila Pacamara El Salvador
Review: ong>Those who value richly spicy, fragrantly wood-toned beverages (certain digestifs and aperitifs, for example).
Coffee Origin: Santa Ana growing region, El Salvador

Name: Guatemala Finca La Bolsa
Review: ong>Aficionados curious about the rare, huge-beaned Maragogipe variety of Arabica. This version displays unusually full mouthfeel and a sweet, spice-and-flowers wood character.

Name: Las Flores Espresso
Review: ong>Those who look for the brightness of a fine contemporary American espresso enveloped in classic balance, depth and roundly nuanced resonance.
Coffee Origin: Santa Maria de Dota valley, Tarrazu growing region, Costa Rica

Name: Kochere Espresso
Review: ong>An assertive and exhilarating shot in the new American mode: bright, sweet, distinctively nuanced.

Name: Zimbabwe AAA New Year’s Gift
Review: ong>Aficionados interested in sampling this now rare, once flourishing coffee origin, and anyone who values a delicately crisp, strawberry-and-nut-toned cup.

Name: El Salvador Finca Medrano Pacamara Nohemi Ventura
Review: ong>A superb, distinctive example of the deep, spicy and berry-toned complexity of the Pacamara variety.
Coffee Origin: Chalatenango growing region, northwestern El Salvador

Name: Guatemala Huehuetenango El Rincon
Review: ong>Those who value vivacity in a cup both sweetly juicy and crisply zesty.

Name: Panama Elida Estate Washed Lot #6
Review: ong>A classic Panama of the old, pre-Gesha days brought to a classic medium roast: soft but resonant, suave, quietly original.

Name: Guatemala El Socorro Maracaturra
Review: ong>Those who value a delicate but zesty cup, light-footed and lively.
Coffee Origin: Palencia, Fraijanes Plateau growing region, central Guatemala

Name: Guatemala Buena Esperanza Lot A
Review: ong>Those who value a fine, classic juxtaposition of a plummy, plump juiciness and crisp nut and cedar.

Name: Guatemala El Injerto Pandora del Carmen Auction-Lot
Review: ong>

Name: Organic Guatemala Rio Azul
Review: ong>A very slight, felicitous hint of ferment complicates the fundamental, natural sweetness of this fine traditionally styled Guatemala.

Name: Honduras Santa Barbara Finca Las Brisas
Review: ong>Those who value the complete, balanced structure and quietly engaging aromatics of a classic Central American cup.

Name: Costa Rica “Herbazu” Finca Leoncio
Review: ong>Those who value the sweetly drying, pungent berry notes of fine Kenyas should enjoy this brisk, elegant experimental Costa Rica.

Name: Ethiopia Jimma Agaro
Review: ong>Those who value a coffee both delicate and lush, pure yet musky and deep.

Name: 100% Jamaica Blue Mountain
Review: ong>Those who value the sweetness, full mouthfeel and sweet cocoa notes that made this celebrated origin famous.
Coffee Origin: Blue Mountain growing region, eastern Jamaica.

Name: Rwanda Silverback Espresso
Review: ong>An espresso both classic in structure and distinctively Central African in its sweet, floral- and berry-toned pungency.

Name: Ecuador “Mama Kilya” Espresso
Review: ong>Superb espresso in the newer style: bright but sweet, intricate in flavor and aroma.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Wote Konga
Review: ong>Those who value a big but balanced version of the lushly sweet, fruit-forward style of “natural” or dried-in-the-fruit coffee.

Name: Burundi Reserve
Review: ong>Those who value depth and resonance in a complexly pungent Central Africa coffee.

Name: Ethiopia Hambela
Review: ong>A fine version of the older-fashioned style of dried-in-the-fruit or “natural” Ethiopia coffee: Chocolate, cherry and brandy; a grown-up dessert in a cup.
Coffee Origin: Hambela district, Oromia growing region, southern Ethiopia

Name: Kenya Nyeri Peaberry
Review: ong>Superb Kenya, extraordinarily bright and juicy but without a trace of sharpness. Aroma and flavor are deeply expressed and engaging.

Name: Ethiopia Sidama Nura Korate Fair-Trade/Organic
Review: ong>Those who prefer a rounder, deeper version of the typical floral-and-cocoa-toned Ethiopia wet-processed cup, and one that is reassuringly certified.
Coffee Origin: Sidama (also Sidamo) growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Panama Lino Esmeralda Geisha Natural
Review: ong>Those who value exhilarating aroma and flavor supported by a complexly expressed structure as crisply dry as it is juicily sweet.
Coffee Origin: Cañas Verdes, Boquete growing region, western Panama.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe
Review: ong>Those who value flowers and sweetness without sentiment: crisp aromatic wood and cacao notes balance a soaring floral richness.

Name: Wayfarer Blend
Review: ong>Those who value a quietly comprehensive cup, with crisp nut and cacao notes and a softening bloom of sweet flowers.

Name: Las Flores Costa Rica
Review: ong>Those who value a crisp, refreshing cup, sweet yet gently drying, with quietly intriguing aromatics.
Coffee Origin: Santa Maria de Dota valley, Tarrazu growing region, Costa Rica.

Name: Ethiopia Sidama Akrabi
Review: ong>Those who value a richly authoritative version of the exhilarating flowers, fruit and cacao Yirgacheffe wet-processed profile.
Coffee Origin: Guji Zone, Sidama Province, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Kenya AA Gakuyuri
Review: ong>A splendid Kenya, classically complete in structure and leaning toward the sweet and floral in its gently pungent aromatics.

Name: Manzano Natural El Salvador
Review: ong>Those who value deep, resonantly complex beverages.
Coffee Origin: Santa Ana growing region, El Salvador.

Name: Jacob’s Espresso
Review: ong>Those who value a versatile espresso with a wide range of aromatic expression, both in the small cup and in milk.
Coffee Origin: Guatemala; Colombia; Costa Rica; Ethiopia; Kenya.

Name: Kenya Embu Gakui Peaberry
Review: ong>Those who value floral seduction and pungent intensity in a classic Kenya.

Name: Kenya AA Kigwandi Estate
Review: ong>A splendid and very characteristic Kenya, seductive yet authoritative, balanced in structure but original in aromatics.

Name: Kenya Gatundu Karinga AB
Review: ong>Those who value resonance and depth in a powerful yet balanced Kenya.

Name: Kenya Mbeguka AA
Review: ong>Those who value a relatively gentle Kenya, sweet at the intersection of peach and flowers.

Name: Kenya Yara Peaberry
Review: ong>Those who value a bright, juicy version of the classic pungently sweet Kenya profile.

Name: Kenya Lenana AB
Review: ong>Those who value classic acidity and balance with a characteristic Kenya complement of chocolate, tart fruit, flowers and herb.

Name: Kenya Karani AA
Review: ong>Those who value originality, particularly the Kenya-inflected kind: imagine the good side of sweet tomato against a backdrop of chocolate and berry.

Name: Kenya Kiambu Peaberry
Review: ong>Classic in structure, distinctively Kenya in flavor and aroma: cherry tomato and chocolate; grapefruit and black currant.

Name: Kenya AA Blue Mountain Ruita I AA
Review: ong>A gently stated, but quite classic, Kenya: the sweetly tart, pungent black currant note softens in a cushion of dark chocolate and molasses-toned sweetness.

Name: Kenya AA Kanake
Review: ong>Those who enjoy the sweet brightness of a classic light-roasted coffee wrapped around the pungent heart of a Kenya.

Name: Kenya Kirinyaga Karimikui AA
Review: ong>Those who value pungent authority in a big, deep, strong-gestured Kenya.

Name: Ka’u Natural Typica
Review: ong>Those who value an explicitly but lightly and elegantly ferment-toned coffee: think oranges and fine brandy.
Coffee Origin: Ka’u growing region, Big Island of Hawaii.

Name: Elida Natural Lot 12 Panama
Review: ong>A very delicate, cider-toned version of the natural or dried-in-the-fruit profile. May particularly appeal to those who enjoy coffees with a vibrant though softly, roundly stated acidity.

Name: Sumatra Ulos Batak
Review: ong>Those who enjoy the syrupy mouthfeel and pungent, unorthodox aroma and flavor of a fine Sumatra.
Coffee Origin: Lintong growing region, North Sumatra Province, Indonesia.

Name: Aroma 19 Blend Coffee Beans
Review: ong>Those who value aromatic originality in their espresso. An unusual though engaging straight shot makes a complex, attractive presence in taller milk drinks.

Name: Tuscany Blend Coffee Beans
Review: ong>This pungent, big-bodied espresso produces a bracing straight shot and projects enough authority to master taller milk drinks.

Name: Bologna Blend Coffee Beans
Review: ong>Those who prefer a light, dry espresso with brisk, invigorating aromatics.

Name: Kochere Ethiopia
Review: ong>Those who value sweetly bright, cleanly delicate coffees with fine balance and citrus, nut and floral vivacity.

Name: Kenya AA Nyeri Wachuri
Review: ong>Those who value a moderately dark-roasted version of the flowers and pungent berry sweetness of a good Kenya.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Buna Ababa
Review: ong>Those who value purity, lucidity and intricacy in a great floral-and-citrus Yirgacheffe cup.

Name: Life Saver Guatemala Organic Finca Santa Rita
Review: ong>Those who value sweetness, balance and classic grace in a fine Central-America style coffee produced with impeccable attention to the environment.

Name: Espresso Blend
Review: ong>Those who value a complex yet finely balanced, medium-roasted espresso.

Name: Espresso Classico
Review: ong>Lives up to the classic epithet: chocolate, cedar, balance and just a touch of bonus brightness and flowers.

Name: Ethiopia Suke Quto Organic
Review: ong>Those who value balance and subtlety.
Coffee Origin: Guji Zone, Oromia Region, Sidamo growing region, south-central Ethiopia.

Name: Ethiopia Kela Kochore
Review: ong>Those who value quiet excitement and delicate thrills.

Name: Ethiopia Hambela Natural
Review: ong>Lovers of big, fruit-toned California cabernets and those coffee drinkers who value a refined but explicit sweet fruit ferment in their natural-processed coffees. Here a richly drying edge complicates the lush, rum-and-chocolate-toned fruit.
Coffee Origin: Hambela district, Oromia growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Decaf Classic House Blend
Review: ong>Those decaf drinkers who enjoy darker roasted espressos with deep, rather intricate aromatic intrigue.

Name: Panama Don Pepe Fully Washed Geisha
Review: ong>An aficionado’s Gesha, high-grown and uncompromising, with extraordinary depth and complexity.

Name: Ethiopia Shakiso
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a sweet but brisk, zesty cup with quietly striking aromatics.
Coffee Origin: Oromia, Sidama (also Sidamo) growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Decaf Ethiopia Sidamo
Review: ong>Decaf drinkers who value a clean, engagingly complex version of one of the world’s great coffee origins.
Coffee Origin: Sidamo (also Sidama) growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Mexico Decaf
Review: ong>Those decaf drinkers who value a delicate but classic traditional American cup, balanced, clean, gently complex.

Name: Decaf Asterisk Organic
Review: ong>The decaffeination process apparently emphasizes the caramel and aromatic wood notes and de-emphasizes fruit and flowers in this simple but crisp, satisfying decaf.
Coffee Origin: Sidama (also Sidamo) growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Decaffeinated El Toro Blend
Review: ong>Sweetness, quietly layered flavor and soft acidity should please decaf drinkers who avoid intense acidity as well as caffeine.

Name: Decaf Pike Place Roast
Review: ong>Should satisfy decaf drinkers who enjoy moderately dark-roasted coffees, despite – or perhaps because of – the odd but intense aroma and flavor, heavy with pungent, woody sweetness.

Name: Golden Mean Espresso Blend
Review: ong>Those who value expressive complexity both in flavor and in structure, where sweet and tart are complicated by a hint of savory.

Name: Konga Ethiopia
Review: ong>A delicate but gently intense version of the great, always intricate Yirgacheffe profile.

Name: Burundi Nyarunasi Muramuya
Review: ong>Lovers of pure, delicate but complex beverages.

Name: Ethiopia Ardi
Review: ong>Those who enjoy aromatically complex beverages that are simultaneously sweet with a brisk, gently drying undercurrent.
Coffee Origin: Sidama (also Sidamo) growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Waykan Guatemala
Review: ong>I am tempted to particularly recommend this coffee to those who enjoy the pungent, complex aroma inside a cigar humidor or the sweeter odor of a cedar cabinet, but that may overly limit the appeal of this coffee, given that the attractive cedar note is just the beginning point of a complex, original profile.

Name: Guji Ethiopia
Review: ong>Those who value an impressively refreshing, sweetly zesty, light-roasted cup.
Coffee Origin: Sidama (also Sidamo) growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Finca La Mula Panama Geisha
Review: ong>Anyone who can afford it.

Name: Direct Fair Trade Organic Espresso Blend
Review: ong>A crisp, gently complex straight shot with a light but smoothly lively mouthfeel; pleasingly brisk and lively in cappuccino and short milk.
Coffee Origin: Sidama, southern Ethiopia; Pangoa, Peru; Yungas, Bolivia.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Oromia
Review: ong>Those who enjoy the crisp resonance and chocolaty complication generated by a moderately dark roast applied to a distinctive green coffee.

Name: Gourmet Blend
Review: ong>Those who value quiet acidity and round, chocolaty balance.

Name: S.O. Espresso Brazil Fazenda Santa Ines
Review: ong>A versatile espresso, richly expressive and complex as a straight shot while maintaining its character and authority in milk.
Coffee Origin: Carmo de Minas growing region, Minas Gerais State, Brazil.

Name: Alemu Kochere Yirgacheffe
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a delicately brisk, gently intricate cup.

Name: Ethiopia Ardi
Review: ong>Those who value syrupy but dry beverages with deep-toned, quietly exotic complication.
Coffee Origin: Sidamo (also Sidama) growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Original Italian Espresso
Review: ong>Classic Italian espresso: balanced, deep, resonant, dominated by a crisply cedary chocolate that carries persuasively into milk.
Coffee Origin: Mogiana growing region, São Paulo State, Brazil; Guatemala; other Central America origins.

Name: Black House
Review: ong>Outstanding choice for those who value depth, resonance, big body and low-toned but lively acidity.
Coffee Origin: Oromia region, southern Ethiopia; Mandheling growing region, northern Sumatra, Indonesia.

Name: Don Pepe’s Excellent Adventure
Review: ong>Those who value smooth but brisk, dry beverages with subtly complex flavor and aroma.
Coffee Origin: Boquete growing region, Panama; Boke, Gamo Gofa Zone, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Sari’s Backyard
Review: ong>A delicate, easy-drinking summery blend with a sneaky, crisply sweet intricacy.

Name: Romance by Paradise
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a briskly dry though lively, complex, quietly exotic cup.

Name: Ride the Edge
Review: ong>Those who value a finely elegant, gentle, meadowy coffee with outstanding social and environmental credentials.
Coffee Origin: Southern Ethiopia; Mexico; northern Sumatra, Indonesia.

Name: Homestead Blend
Review: ong>Fine balance in a quiet, graceful blend with unusually sweet citrus.
Coffee Origin: Yirgacheffe growing region, southern Ethiopia; West Java, Indonesia.

Name: The Flatlander Signature Blend
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a balanced, quietly lively lighter-roasted cup with a particularly elegant floral note.

Name: Island Reserve
Review: ong>Those who value classic balance and quiet completeness.

Name: Naturals Special Blend
Review: ong>This unusual blend should please those who value full, syrupy body, low acidity and a rich, molasses-toned fruit.

Name: Huila Colombia
Review: ong>Those who enjoy intense though nuanced acidity; a fine high-altitude Colombia in the classic style.

Name: Selian Tanzania
Review: ong>Those who enjoy beverages that juxtapose juicy sweetness with the gently brisk and bracing.
Coffee Origin: Arusha growing region, Mt. Meru, Tanzania.

Name: Kenya Gachatha AA
Review: ong>Unique version of the great Kenya profile: intricately floral, honey-sweet, brisk but juicy.

Name: Hummingbird Espresso
Review: ong>Those who prefer a classic espresso, poised and complete.

Name: Burundi Kayanza Province Mpanga Washing Station
Review: ong>Superb balance in a cup that combines chocolaty sweetness, bright fruit and a pleasingly dry hint of aromatic wood.

Name: Ethiopian Yirgacheffe Kela Kochore
Review: ong>Those who value a quietly exotic cup with an unusual balance of walnut-like briskness and juicy mango-like fruit.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Dabub Matebya
Review: ong>Those who value a richly and roundly bright cup with a pleasingly full mouthfeel and quietly exotic complexity.

Name: Yemen Haraaz Red A+
Review: ong>Buy it both for the exotic origin and the exotic cup. The finest example of a Yemen to reach us in some time. Giddy, almost disconcertingly sweet complexity supported by a solid structure.
Coffee Origin: Haraz (also spelled Haraaz) growing region, north-central Yemen

Name: Guatemala Waykan
Review: ong>Lovers of comfort. A nicely balanced coffee with a quiet but engaging aromatic profile: nut, chocolate, a shimmer of flowers.

Name: El Salvador Finca Loma La Gloria
Review: ong>Don’t expect the classic, nor tropical fruit and flowers. In some respects one of a kind. A beverage analogy might be a heavily but very fragrantly hopped IPA.
Coffee Origin: El Boqueron, Volcan de San Salvador, El Salvador.

Name: Guatemala Finca Santa Isabel
Review: ong>Deeply expressed, fruity dark chocolate is the appeal here, along with a general impression of plush viscosity. Not a classic coffee, but a distinctive one. Excellent social and environmental credentials.

Name: Ethiopia Sidama Ardi
Review: ong>Those who can handle gracefully stated extravagance.
Coffee Origin: Guji Zone, Sidama Province, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Kenya Karagoto
Review: ong>Those who prefer a balanced, softly bright version of a classic Kenya.

Name: Rwanda Nyanza Kirezi
Review: ong>Those who enjoy quiet brightness and a fruit character that is simultaneously cleanly elegant and discreetly lush.

Name: Colombia Caldas Laderas del Tapias
Review: ong>Classic Latin-American coffee, poised and delicately rich in structure, resonantly engaging in aroma and flavor.

Name: Brazil Sitio Baixadao
Review: ong>Roasted to just shy of the second crack, this is not the way this coffee tasted to the Cup of Excellence jury that, on the basis of what was certainly a light-to-medium sample roast, awarded it an unprecedented score of 95. Nevertheless, at this moderately dark roast it’s a fine, elegantly chocolaty coffee with engaging hints of citrus and berry.
Coffee Origin: Mantiqeiras de Minas growing region, Minas Gerais State, Brazil.

Name: Organic Colombia AAA Microlot
Review: ong>Lovers of the classic Latin-America cup: nothing flashy, nothing out of balance here, just a roundly and quietly complete cup.

Name: Burundi Kayanza Ninga
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a gently tart cup with a balanced range of floral, fruit and crisp aromatic wood notes.

Name: Kenya Sangana
Review: ong>Those who enjoy moderately dark roasts that preserve some taste of place, in this case a characteristic Kenya pungent berry and (here a roast-influenced) dark chocolate.

Name: 100% Kona Coffee
Review: ong>Kona is not a particularly distinctive origin to start with, and here a rather aggressive dark roast doesn’t leave much origin character behind for speculation. We do get some scorchy, buttery dark chocolate, however, and a tickle of lemon.
Coffee Origin: Kona growing region, “Big Island” of Hawaii.

Name: Brazil Sertãozinho
Review: ong>Whitener may sweeten the chocolate and smooth the mouthfeel.

Name: Ethiopia Washed Limu Gera
Review: ong>Exceptionally balanced, delicately complete version of the great southern Ethiopia wet-processed profile.

Name: Mexico Honey Huatusco
Review: ong>The fragrant musk, aromatic wood and hint of chocolate may make this unusual coffee a particularly good way to finish a dinner.

Name: House Blend (Espresso)
Review: ong>A classic darker-roasted espresso: the roast develops depth and pleasingly pungent dark chocolate, nut and aromatic wood notes.

Name: Ethiopia Aricha
Review: ong>Offers extraordinary aromatic intrigue: complex, exotic, original.

Name: Ace Espresso
Review: ong>Balanced and vivacious espresso: citrusy brightness rounded by chocolaty depth and plump mouthfeel.

Name: Mutwari Tanzania Peaberry
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a richly tart, juicy cup with depth and fullness.

Name: Colombia El Mango
Review: ong>Splendidly balanced, quietly complete coffee: juicy, refreshing, vivacious.

Name: Burundi Shamba
Review: ong>A quietly exhilarating coffee with a particularly expressive, lively acidity.

Name: Milepost Colombia Finca La Arenosa
Review: ong>Those who enjoy tart, dry beverages with engaging complexity.

Name: FTO Congo Sopacdi Cooperative
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a spicy, delicate floral character in a nicely balanced organic/Fair-Trade coffee.
Coffee Origin: Kalehe, Southern Kivu, Democratic Republic of the Congo.

Name: Papua New Guinea Mile High
Review: ong>A coffee that invites adjectives like smooth, svelte, supple. Peachy sweetness, crisp cacao.
Coffee Origin: Kainantu district, Eastern Highlands Province, Papua New Guinea.

Name: Colombia Special Process Microlot 511 “Memory Orchard” Espresso
Review: ong>A classic espresso on steroids: big, syrupy, complex.

Name: Costa Rica “The Wind Bell” Espresso
Review: ong>A deeply expressed dark chocolate anchors complex floral, fruit and spice notes: complex and invigorating.

Name: Colombia Special Process Microlot 504 “Higher and Higher” Espresso
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a tartly bright, yet deeply resonant and complex espresso.

Name: Rwanda Coproca
Review: ong>Those who enjoy red table wines with lots of both fruit and oak may particularly enjoy this plump, juicy but brisk Rwanda.

Name: Costa Rica Sonora Bourbon Natural
Review: ong>Simply a fine, balanced, complete cup, as absolutely poised and pure as dried-in-the-fruit coffees get. The honey and peach notes are particularly appealing.

Name: Ethiopia Kochere
Review: ong>An unusually (and impressively) rich and resonant version of the floral and sweet-citrus Yirgacheffe wet-processed profile.

Name: Nicaragua La Florencia
Review: ong>Anyone who enjoys depth, full mouthfeel and quiet complexity. Aficionados may be particularly interested in sampling a fine, tactfully light-roasted example of a dried-in-the-fruit coffee from Nicaragua, an origin that until now has never produced a high-end version of the type.

Name: Panama Los Lajones
Review: ong>Those who prefer gentle acidity and a roundly sweet-toned cup with quietly original aromatics and an impressive ecological back story.
Coffee Origin: Eastern slopes of Volcan Baru, western Panama.

Name: The Secret Coffee
Review: ong>The fruit notes remain extraordinarily sweet and juicy in this very light-roasted espresso, offering brightness and vivacity without sharpness.

Name: Butler Café Family Series: Yirgacheffe Natural Process
Review: ong>Big, syrupy espresso with powerful presence and a wide range of sensory expression, from floral sweetness through bright strawberry to resonantly savory suggestions of nut and aromatic wood.

Name: Panama Lerida
Review: ong>Those who enjoy delicately pure, gently bright, quietly complex coffees in the classic Panama style.
Coffee Origin: Boquete growing region, Chiriqui Province, western Panama.

Name: Yirgacheffe Concerto Aramo
Review: ong>Those who enjoy the subtle exhilaration of a pure, lighter-roast Yirgacheffe: honey, flowers, nut-toned chocolate.

Name: Panama Finca Hartmann
Review: ong>Spectacular array of aroma and flavor notes, shifting with little revelations clear to the bottom of the cup.

Name: Sumatra Ulos Batak
Review: ong>
Coffee Origin: Lintong growing region, North Sumatra Province, Indonesia.

Name: Guatemala La Esperanza
Review: ong>

Name: Guatemala El Diamante
Review: ong>Richly sumptuous and quietly original. Displays sensation both deep and complex.

Name: Pomona Blend
Review: ong>Coffee adventurers interested in how much coffee can surprise us with subtle new variations aroma and flavor.

Name: House Espresso Blend
Review: ong>Classic moderately-dark-roasted espresso with a simple but attractive array of aromatics: chocolate, flowers, sweet citrus, pungent aromatic wood. Sustainably credentialed.

Name: Espresso Blend
Review: ong>A crowd-pleasing, complete espresso.
Coffee Origin: Panama; Sidamo and Yirgacheffe growing regions, southern Ethiopia; Bolivia; Brazil.

Name: Seattle Space Blend
Review: ong>Excitement first: intensity and a big, complex range of sensation.

Name: Proud Goat Espresso Blend
Review: ong>A classically poised and gracefully complete espresso, free of flaw or affectation.

Name: Dharma Blend Espresso
Review: ong>New American classic: a little tart but not too tart, good balancing chocolate; consistent through the profile; versatile.

Name: Pantheon Blend No.1
Review: ong>Not your usual pungent, scorched-cedar Starbucks espresso blend. On the other hand, not a bright, crisply sweet lighter-roasted espresso in the newer style either. Unfortunately, short of traveling to Seattle and buying this blend in person at the new Starbucks Reserve Roastery readers apparently will have no way to decide for themselves whether Starbucks split the difference felicitously between dark and medium when it roasted this blend. The Starbucks Reserve coffees sold online or off-site are roasted much darker than this blend. Nice coffees, fancy names, but, well, just your same old dark-roasted Starbucks.

Name: Division by Zero Espresso
Review: ong>A gently bright, floral-toned espresso in the newer style, vivacious and delicately lively.
Coffee Origin: 50% Yirgacheffe Ethiopia; 25% Papua New Guinea; 25% Brazil.

Name: Ganesha Espresso
Review: ong>No matter whose reading you follow, a fine, complete, complex espresso.
Coffee Origin: Rwanda; Costa Rica; Yirgacheffe growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Wolf Moon Seasonal Espresso
Review: ong>Poised, elegant espresso in the newer lighter-roasted style, with a delicate, crisply layered complexity and an understated but vivacious brightness.

Name: Top Shelf Espresso
Review: ong>One seldom has an opportunity to sample a coffee as rare and distinguished as the Gesha component of this blend in an espresso context, and even less often at very light roast and a relatively reasonable price. If you have the cash and curiosity, give this one a try, but expect a high-toned complexity alive with flowers, fruit and an exotic aromatic wood.

Name: Revelation Espresso
Review: ong>Those who enjoy high-toned flowers and bright fruit in a light, lively espresso with an anchoring cocoa-toned complication.

Name: Dawning Espresso
Review: ong>A very slightly darkish roast develops pleasing savory-sweet depth and resonance. Lovers of stouts, porters and oaky red wines may particularly enjoy this blend.
Coffee Origin: Brazil; Panama; Mexico; Costa Rica; Guatemala.

Name: Sillvia Solkiln N2 Level 95
Review: ong>For those with substantial coffee budgets this is a stunning, memorable coffee, accessible yet vivid and extraordinary.

Name: Sweet Maria’s Acatenango Gesha
Review: ong>A subtle, appealing, accessible yet memorable version of the great Gesha profile.

Name: Monserrate Colombia
Review: ong>Its resonant depth and pungent berry enveloped in floral sweetness suggest the rounder, deeper style of Kenya. Should appeal to those who enjoy intensity without assertive brightness.

Name: Nagy Peaberry
Review: ong>A discreet darker roast develops the chocolate and musky floral notes in this interesting China coffee.

Name: Buena Vista Farm Colombia
Review: ong>Those who enjoy brisk rather than bright coffees: lavender, nut and aromatic wood supported by a pleasing caramelly sweetness.

Name: Rwanda Dukunde Kawa Musasa
Review: ong>A discreet and understated edge-of-dark roast develops the chocolate and berryish fruit in this juicy Rwanda.

Name: Organic Popayan Colombia
Review: ong>Those who enjoy gentle balance and delicately resonant aroma and flavor. A subtle and cleanly expressed organic/Fair Trade-certified coffee.

Name: Nicaragua Finca La Joya Villa Lobos Natural Santa Lucila
Review: ong>An unapologetic, thoroughly engaging, very light-roasted version of the dried-in-the-fruit or “natural” processed profile, alive with whisky-like suggestions and unorthodox complexity.
Coffee Origin: Nueva Segovia Department, Diplito growing region, Nicaragua.

Name: Colombia Arabica Mezzo Espresso Capsule
Review: ong>Nespresso capsule machine owners who enjoy delicate, sweetly bright espresso with a quiet, chocolaty presence in short milk. Best at the ristretto setting.
Coffee Origin: Huila Department, Colombia; northern Sumatra, Indonesia.

Name: Keremara AA Kenya
Review: ong>A striking but very accessible coffee. The combination of flowers, chocolate, sweet citrus and a pungent, incense-like note is unusual, and supported by a structure both balanced and seductive.

Name: Tchembe Gedeo Ethiopia
Review: ong>The sweetly bright, buttery juiciness of certain tropical fruits, balanced by refined cacao and aromatic wood notes. Distinctive and superb.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Gedeo
Review: ong>Exhilaratingly sweet and floral yet completed and balanced rendition of the great Yirgacheffe washed profile.

Name: Finca La Aurora Camilina Geisha
Review: ong>A grand, brilliant coffee that presents both juicy seduction and challenging intensity and complexity.
Coffee Origin: Piedra Candela, Chiriqui Province, far western Panama.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Konga Zone Dry Process
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a richly and sweetly tart cup with deep-toned, complexly resonant aromatics.
Coffee Origin: Konga micro-region, Yirgacheffe growing region, south-central Ethiopia.

Name: Ethiopian Yirgacheffe Wenago Natural
Review: ong>Those who enjoy beverages that are both bracingly brisk and complexly floral. Dry martini drinkers, for example, or lovers of the more aromatic style of hoppy beers.

Name: Sumatra Lake Toba Peaberry
Review: ong>Particularly striking for its range of sensation, from lush flowers through juicy stone fruit and hints of spice and herb, supported by a complete, balanced structure. Should be a quite versatile cup, attractive both black and with whitener.
Coffee Origin: Lake Toba growing region, northern Sumatra, Indonesia.

Name: Sumatra Ulos Batak
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a sweet-savory, zesty, citrusy cup.
Coffee Origin: Lintong growing region, North Sumatra Province, Indonesia.

Name: Sumatra Aceh Adsenia Ketiara
Review: ong>Those who enjoy depth, richness and an unusual juxtaposition of creamy sensations with crisp in a quietly dramatic cup.
Coffee Origin: Aceh growing region, northwestern Sumatra, Indonesia.

Name: Sumatra KUD Silimakuta AAA
Review: ong>Those coffee drinkers nostalgic for a hint of the old-fashioned earthy, full-bodied Sumatra cup updated in a thoroughly refined rendition: a touch earthy and fruity but sweet-toned, subtle, nuanced.
Coffee Origin: Lake Toba growing region, North Sumatra Province, Indonesia.

Name: Sumatra Ulos Batak
Review: ong>A hint of the traditional foresty Sumatra character, moist fallen leaves and cedary flowers, enveloped in a balanced, softly lively structure.
Coffee Origin: Lintong growing region, Lake Toba, North Sumatra Province, Indonesia.

Name: Sumatra Gayo
Review: ong>Classic wet-hulled Sumatra in the new refined mode, with the celebrated earth notes discreet, elegant, crisply cacao- and peach-toned.
Coffee Origin: Gayo or Aceh growing region, Aceh Province, northern Sumatra, Indonesia.

Name: Sumatra Lintong Ulos Batak
Review: ong>This fine, classic wet-hulled Sumatra almost suggests Kenya with its crisp, sweetly tart, berryish richness.
Coffee Origin: Lintong growing region, North Sumatra Province, Indonesia.

Name: Sumatra Lintong
Review: ong>The refined style of wet-hulled Sumatra character is very lightly and delicately expressed here, in this tartly lively, lighter-roasted rendition.
Coffee Origin: Lintong growing region, North Sumatra Province, Indonesia.

Name: Sumatra Organic Aceh Ketiara
Review: ong>A sweet though dry tendency runs through this profile, animating a rather original aromatic that coffee drinkers who lean toward dry but lively white table wines and the more aromatic style of hoppy beers may particularly enjoy. A very good value for the price.
Coffee Origin: Aceh growing region, northwestern Sumatra, Indonesia.

Name: Sulawesi Tana Toraja
Review: ong>A combination of malty richness and gentle brightness make this an engaging version of a wet-hulled Sulawesi.
Coffee Origin: Toraja growing region, South Sulawesi, Indonesia.

Name: Ethiopian Washed Kochere G1 SO Espresso
Review: ong>This intricate and richly composed single-origin espresso should excite espresso adventurers while satisfying classicists with its depth, balance and sweetness.
Coffee Origin: Kochere, Yirgacheffe growing region, south-central Ethiopia.

Name: Body Flavor Espresso
Review: ong>Those who enjoy big, richly pungent, fudgy espressos.

Name: Peru Grade 1 Cenfrocafe Dark Roast
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a low-toned, resonant cup with suggestions of floral herb and dark chocolate.

Name: Colombia Granja La Esperanza Grand Cru Mokka
Review: ong>An opportunity to enjoy a very rare and distinctive yet easy-drinking variety: crisp yet lush, exotic though finally balanced.
Coffee Origin: Valle del Cauca growing region, Colombia.

Name: Villa Loyola Colombia
Review: ong>Lovers of very pure but distinctive light-roasted coffees: fresh, breezy and meadowy.

Name: Bolivia Canto de Bolivar
Review: ong>This quietly complex, crisply chocolate-toned cup should please those who prefer the subtle and silky to the bright and assertive in a Fair Trade- and organic-certified coffee.
Coffee Origin: Caranavi Province, La Paz Department, Bolivia.

Name: Jakarta Blend
Review: ong>Those who enjoy quiet intrigue.
Coffee Origin: Aceh growing region, northern Sumatra, Indonesia; Antigua growing region, Guatemala; Kaffa Forest growing region, southwestern Ethiopia.

Name: Panama Esmeralda Geisha
Review: ong>Amazing version of the routinely amazing Gesha profile, as seductive as it is original.
